posts.name: Justin | 6925 Alumentor
posts.cooked:
We are currently at the PCH district championship and noticed a problem with our robot. Towards the end of the match we start to have battery issues and our swerve starts skipping and performance is affected in our other subsystems. In our most recent match this happened really early on towards the middle of the match. I looked at the driver station logs and it doesn’t look like the current limits are working. IMG_2323 3024×4032 3.28 MB However our code seems to correctly set the currents and it shows it working on phoenix tuner. Code is here: GitHub - BTYWAR/6925-Crescendo

IMG_2323 3024×4032 3.28 MB

IMG_2323 3024×4032 3.28 MB

Electrically wise it seems fine and we are using 40 amp breakers.

Does anyone know what our issue is?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Did you enable the current limits after setting them? It’s a new fun feature this year, they’re off by default!

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: sounds electrical. Pull your wires from the PDH inspect and reseat them. Make sure main breaker wires are secure.

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked:
I believe you want a stator current limit, not a supply.

Read more about it in this post:

Current Limiting TalonFX values Programming

posts.name: Justin | 6925 Alumentor
posts.cooked: Does anyone know what I should set the stator current limit to and how I would do it. We are using all krakens for swerve. Thanks!

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked: We have ours set to 80 but I’ve seen anywhere from 40 to 120

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
Given your supply current threshold, depending on your supply time threshold your supply current limits are more likely than not working as intended. You could tighten the thresholds to strengthen the current limit. However, supply currents are not sufficient to prevent wheel slip, only brownouts and breaker trips. For wheel slip, you’ll want to use stator current limits.

Using stator current limits to prevent wheel slippage is dependent on your robot and is typically anywhere from 80–120 A. Stator current limits also do limit supply current to an extent. The average supply current draw for a given stator current limit is about half the stator current limit, while the peak supply current draw is equivalent to the stator current limit.

So for example, an 80 A stator current limit has an average supply current draw of around 40 A, going from around 15 A drawn at stall to 80 A at around 4800 RPM , after which current draw drops rapidly.

If you find that a reasonable stator limit is not sufficient to prevent brownouts or breakers tripping, you can combine it with a supply current limit. Stator current is directly proportional to torque and acceleration, whereas supply current limits do not have as significant of an impact on torque output.

Andrew_L:

Did you enable the current limits after setting them? It’s a new fun feature this year, they’re off by default!

Just to quickly clarify something, this isn’t anything new; we’ve always had current limit enable flags (even pre-Phoenix 5), and we currently default them to false because user-configured current limits should not be necessary to prevent hardware damage with the Talon FX.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Jacob
posts.cooked: Thank you for the explanation, it was extremely helpful! Just want to make sure that I am understanding correctly: are you suggesting that we remove the supply current limit, then set our stator current limit to somewhere between 80 and 120? Then if we continue to see amperage issues, we should add the supply limits back?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: It’s up to you and your team. Leaving the supply current limit in place alongside the stator current limit is the safest option. However, we’ve found that many teams get by just fine with a stator current limit alone, as the motor does not spend a lot of time in the section of the stator-limited motor curve with higher supply current draw.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
Another thing to consider, particularly if your vertical center of gravity is not all the way down on the floor, is that under hard acceleration, some of your wheels will have significantly more traction than others – on some light robots we’ve been able to lift the “front” wheels off the ground entirely, leaving only two real drive motors.  Even this year, with relatively heavy robots, we’ve seen plenty of wheel-lift on the field.

When that happens, you’d really like to devote all your “current budget” to the wheels actually touching the floor, even if that means they’re drawing 100 amps each.  In general, you’d kinda like to have a budget for all the drive motors, and distribute that budget depending on what the robot is doing.

To do that, you could impose acceleration limits on the whole drivetrain, rather than current limits on each motor.

posts.name: Jacob
posts.cooked: While that makes sense, I don’t think it applies to us We have a very low center of gravity and a max weight robot. Thanks for the suggestion though!

posts.name: Jacob
posts.cooked: Alright, we will do some testing with it. Thank you so much!
